channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Queen's Speech targets immigration
item.description: The government announces tougher rules for migrants as it outlines its programme for the next year in the Queen's Speech.

item.title: Ferguson to retire at end of season
item.description: Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson is stepping down, after winning a record 38 trophies in 26 years at the club.

item.title: Deaths as ship rams Genoa tower
item.description: At least six people have died and four are missing after a ship crashed into a control tower in the Italian port of Genoa, officials say.

item.title: April Jones 999 call played to jury
item.description: The 999 call reporting April Jones's disappearance is played to the jury in the trial of the man accused of abducting and murdering the five-year-old.

item.title: Arrests over $50m diamond heist
item.description: Police arrest 31 people over the theft of $50m of diamonds from a plane at Brussels airport, one of the world's largest robberies of gems.

item.title: Police to quiz Cleveland suspects
item.description: Police in Cleveland, Ohio, are due to question three men suspected of kidnapping three women and keeping them hostage for about a decade.

item.title: Child abuse probe at Menuhin school
item.description: Allegations of historical child abuse at the music school founded by violinist Yehudi Menuhin are being investigated by police.

item.title: Sainsbury's sales up as profits fall
item.description: Sainsbury's reports a slight fall in full-year pre-tax profits, despite rising sales, and confirms it is taking full ownership of Sainsbury's Bank

item.title: Review into private eye murder case
item.description: The Home Office is to announce an independent review into the murder of private investigator Daniel Morgan in south London in 1987.

item.title: Battle of the Atlantic commemorated
item.description: Marking the anniversary of the Battle of the Atlantic

item.title: Tributes paid to 'giant' Harryhausen
item.description: George Lucas, Nick Park and other directors pay tribute to visual effects master Ray Harryhausen following his death at the age of 92.

item.title: Madonna sells painting for $7.2m
item.description: A Cubist painting by Fernand Leger owned by pop star Madonna is auctioned for $7.2 million (Â£4.7m) in New York.

item.title: Cold War hope for bats under attack
item.description: Cold War bunkers are the latest attempt to save bats from white-nose syndrome, a disease that has killed up to 6.7 million bats in the US and Canada.

item.title: Plan to simplify pensions and rights
item.description: Changes to the state pension, clearer rights for consumers, and measures on energy and water, are among the government's legislative programme set out in the Queen's Speech.

item.title: Bank accounts will be 'open to all'
item.description: European residents will have the right to open a basic bank account in any country of the EU and compare the fees charged by providers, under new plans.

item.title: Fresh cyber-monitoring move planned
item.description: The government promises fresh proposals to tackle crime in cyberspace by better matching IP addresses to people, after ditching its Communications Data Bill.

item.title: Probation 'given to all offenders'
item.description: All offenders released from prison in England and Wales would receive at least 12 months' probation, under new plans announced in the Queen's Speech.

item.title: Social care 'facing bleak future'
item.description: The social care system in England is facing a bleak future despite the planned changes as services have been forced into budget cuts, council chiefs say.

item.title: Benefits of sun 'may outweigh risks'
item.description: The health benefits of exposing skin to sunlight may far outweigh the risk of developing skin cancer, according to Edinburgh University scientists.

item.title: Cambridge to tutor A-level physics
item.description: Academics from Cambridge University are to help tutor sixth-form physics students across the UK to prepare them better for university study.

item.title: Oxbridge beats world in key subjects
item.description: Oxford and Cambridge universities are the best places to study seven key academic subjects, according to a new international table.

item.title: App taps clues to your happiness
item.description: An app designed to follow personal moods has been launched by researchers at the Cambridge Computer Laboratory.

item.title: Syria 'cut off from the internet'
item.description: Web traffic in Syria plunges to zero overnight, in what appears to be the second internet blackout in six months.

item.title: Ancient bone-headed dinosaur found
item.description: Scientists have announced the discovery of a new species of bone-headed dinosaur, which is the oldest in North America, and possibly the world.

item.title: Satellite to monitor Earth's forests
item.description: A satellite that can "weigh" the Earth's forests has just been given the go ahead by the European Space Agency.

item.title: Metal star arrested over murder plot
item.description: Tim Lambesis, lead singer of US heavy metal band As I Lay Dying, is arrested on suspicion of attempting to plot the murder of his estranged wife.

item.title: Award-winning DJ Rauhofer dies
item.description: Peter Rauhofer, the DJ behind the Grammy-winning disco remix of Cher's track Believe, dies in New York aged 48.

item.title: The Apprentice v the Law of Jante
item.description: Why the Apprentice candidates' boasts would get short shrift across the North Sea in Scandinavia.

item.title: I was the Chinese Girl
item.description: In 1950, a teenager in a Cape Town laundrette was spotted by a Russian artist, who made her face one of the most famous in the world

item.title: Lotus technical director steps down
item.description: Lotus technical director James Allison, one of the most highly regarded design engineers in Formula 1, is to leave the team.

item.title: Robson splits from coach Krajan
item.description: Laura Robson splits from coach Zeljko Krajan after only nine months together, having made the decision before the Madrid Masters.

item.title: Wigan 2-3 Swansea
item.description: Wigan's hopes of staying in the Premier League hang in the balance as Swansea come from behind to win at the DW Stadium.

item.title: Djokovic suffers shock Dimitrov loss
item.description: World number one Novak Djokovic loses to Bulgarian Grigor Dimitrov in the second round of the Madrid Open.

item.title: Man City 1-0 West Brom
item.description: Manchester City qualify for the Champions League as Edin Dzeko's first-half strike gives them victory against West Brom.

item.title: Family 'may have kept 100 slaves'
item.description: More than 100 people may have been held in captivity and forced to work by a Bedfordshire family, it is claimed.

item.title: Tia Sharp 'idolised' murder accused
item.description: Schoolgirl Tia Sharp was very close to the man accused of murdering her, the Old Bailey hears.

item.title: Man dies after being shot in leg
item.description: A 22-year-old man from the Scottish Borders dies in hospital after being shot in the leg at a rural location outside Hawick.

item.title: Queen's Speech contains Union pledge
item.description: The UK government pledges in the Queen's Speech to continue "making the case" for Scotland to remain part of the Union.

item.title: A5 cash 'must go to other roads'
item.description: The Stormont executive is being urged to reallocate money earmarked for the stalled A5 to other roads projects.

item.title: Â£20m wind farm will be opened
item.description: A Â£20m wind farm in County Antrim will be officially opened on Wednesday.

item.title: Tests 'will help struggling pupils'
item.description: Pupils aged seven to 14 begin sitting new reading and literacy tests in schools across Wales as part of efforts to drive up standards.

item.title: Anglesey 'coalition blow for Plaid'
item.description: The leader of the Plaid Cymru group on Anglesey council says he is disappointed that Labour and independents are discussing going into coalition.

item.title: 'Many dead' in Nigeria militant raid
item.description: Fifty-five people have been killed in a raid by Islamist militant group Boko Haram in Nigeria's north-eastern Borno state, the military says.

item.title: Pakistani UN soldier killed in Congo
item.description: A Pakistani UN peacekeeper is killed in an ambush by unknown assailants in eastern DR Congo, which the UN chief describes as a "war crime".

item.title: Imran Khan 'recovering' in hospital
item.description: Leading Pakistani politician Imran Khan is recuperating in hospital after falling off a makeshift lift at an election rally in Lahore, doctors say.

item.title: Malaysia opposition set for rally
item.description: Malaysia's opposition is set for a rally against alleged fraud in the recent election, even as police said the gathering was illegal.

item.title: PKK rebels 'begin leaving Turkey'
item.description: Fighters from the PKK Kurdish rebel group begin leaving Turkey for their safe havens in Iraq under a ceasefire, according to Kurdish sources.

item.title: German immigration from Med surges
item.description: Germany sees its biggest immigration rise in nearly 20 years, with many more arrivals from southern Europe.

item.title: Two jailed for Chile priest kidnap
item.description: A Chilean court sentences two ex-navy officers for abducting Anglo-Chilean priest Michael Woodward, who disappeared during Gen Pinochet's rule in 1973.

item.title: Brazil bus rape suspect arrested
item.description: A teenager suspected of raping a woman at gunpoint after robbing passengers on a public bus in Rio de Janeiro has turned himself in, police say.

item.title: Russia and US agree Syria conference
item.description: Russia and the US say they have agreed to work towards holding an international conference to find a political solution to the conflict in Syria.

item.title: Hawking 'boycotts' Israel conference
item.description: Professor Stephen Hawking has pulled out of a high-profile Israeli conference, apparently in support of an academic boycott of the country.

item.title: US military sex assaults on rise
item.description: As Pentagon figures show a rise in sexual harassment and assaults in the US military, President Obama says it will no longer be tolerated.

item.title: Insanity plea for 'Batman gunman'
item.description: The man accused of killing 12 in the July massacre at a Batman film in Colorado intends to plead not guilty by reason of insanity, his lawyers say.

item.title: Day in pictures: 7 May 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 7 May

item.title: In pictures: Cleveland women rescued
item.description: Found alive in a house in Cleveland, Ohio

item.title: In pictures: Surviving camp life in Mogadishu
item.description: Surviving camp life in Mogadishu

item.title: Day in pictures: 6 May 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 6 May

item.title: In pictures: Bank holiday sunshine
item.description: Warm temperatures on the May bank holiday

item.title: In pictures: Mexico's Cinco de Mayo
item.description: Mexicans celebrating Cinco de Mayo

item.title: In pictures: Violent Dhaka protests
item.description: Violence in the Bangladeshi capital

item.title: Week in pictures: 27 April - 3 May 2013
item.description: A selection of photos from the news

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs approve the Growth and Infrastructure Bill, but Labour deem parts of the bill "ridiculous".

item.title: VIDEO: Antarctic trek team battle elements
item.description: Bad weather and dangerous crevasses have slowed the progress of the team trying to become the first to cross Antarctica during the polar winter.

item.title: VIDEO: 'I paid Â£54 for four ice creams'
item.description: Two British couples were charged Â£54 (64 euros) for four ice cream cones, while on holiday in Rome.

item.title: VIDEO: Gas tanker explodes in Mexico City
item.description: At least 20 people have been killed and 36 injured by a gas tanker exploding on a motorway in a suburb of Mexico City, officials say.

item.title: VIDEO: Imran Khan injured in stage fall
item.description: Imran Khan, one of Pakistan's most prominent politicians, has been injured after falling from an elevated platform at an election rally in Lahore.

item.title: VIDEO: Windsor building collapses after fire
item.description: More than 80 firefighters have been tackling a blaze which caused a building in Windsor town centre to partially collapse.

item.title: VIDEO: 'A torpedo coming straight for us'
item.description: Royal Navy veteran Derek Traylen remembers his experiences in the Battle of the Atlantic on the 70th anniversary of its climax.

item.title: AUDIO: Luton airport testing 'ash-proof planes'
item.description: A tonne of volcanic ash has been flown to Luton airport to test equipment designed to stop another ash cloud crisis.

item.title: AUDIO: Sexsomnia 'is a real condition'
item.description: Matthew Walker, professor of neurology at the National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery in London, says the condition sexsomnia "does exist" and "is a very real condition".

item.title: Ferguson's role in Man Utd success
item.description: Sir Alex Ferguson's role in Man Utd's financial success

item.title: The surprising uses for birdsong
item.description: Can birdsong make you open a bank account?

item.title: The 1953 technology used to climb Everest
item.description: The oxygen tank that stopped the conquest of Everest

item.title: Ohio captives: What next?
item.description: How women recover from captivity

item.title: The world's most sleep-starved students
item.description: Where are the world's most sleep-starved young people?

item.title: Cannabis cash cow?
item.description: Will legalised cannabis mean boom-time in part of the US?

item.title: VIDEO: The houses designed to last just 10 years
item.description: Residents of two estates reflect as their homes face demolition

item.title: Royal Opera premieres fairytale ballet
item.description: The new ballet exploring an enduring folk tale

item.title: The Queenâs Speech: Power and Majesty
item.description: A message about the balance of power, wrapped in ermine

item.title: What price work experience?
item.description: The internships being sold to rich teenagers for Â£5,000 a place
